snippet: Scientists have discovered that whales can “close” their ears, decreasing their sensitivity to noises underwater.
abstract: Team of Hawaiian researchers led by Dr Paul E Nachtigall discovers that whales can decrease the sensitivity of their hearing to protect their ears from loud noise; finding is key to an ongoing debate about human-generated noise pollution in the ocean, which has long been known to cause temporary or permanent hearing loss for more than a quarter-million sea creatures every year.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered that whales can “close” their ears, decreasing their sensitivity to noises underwater.

headline.seo: Whales Show Signs of Coping With Man-Made Noise Underwater
headline.main: Whales, Somehow, Are Coping With Humans’ Din
headline.print_headline: Learning to Cope With Underwater Din
